1.verse: God created the first person, our forefather, Adam. His lineage descended nine generations until the flood: Seth, Enosh,

2.verse: Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,

3.verse: Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech, and Noah.

4.verse: Our ancestor Noah had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. From these, three distinct nations arose.

5.verse: The history of Israel begins with the creation of the world. The sons of Japheth fathered the nations north of Israel. They were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.

6.verse: The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah.

7.verse: The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.

8.verse: Three sons of Ham fathered the nations south of Israel. They were Cush (the Ethiopians), Mizraim (the Egyptians), and Put (the northern Africans). Noah condemned Ham’s fourth son, Canaan, whose descendants we conquered.

9.verse: The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca; the sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.

10.verse: Cush fathered Nimrod (the first hero on earth).

11.verse: Mizraim fathered the people of Lud, Anam, Lehab, Naphtuh,

12.verse: Pathrus, Casluh (from whom the Philistines descended), and Caphtor.

13.verse: Canaan was the forefather of our eastern neighbors: Sidon (his first son), Heth,

14.verse: the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,

15.verse: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,

16.verse: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.

17.verse: Shem fathered the Semitic nations. His sons were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram. Aram fathered Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.

18.verse: Arpachshad fathered Shelah, and Shelah fathered Eber.

19.verse: Eber had two sons, Peleg (whose name means “divided” because the earth was divided during his life) and his brother, Joktan.

20.verse: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,

21.verse: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,

22.verse: Ebal, Abimael, Sheba,

23.verse: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab.

24.verse: Our ancestry descended nine generations directly from Shem: Arpachshad, Shelah,

25.verse: Eber, Peleg, Reu,

26.verse: Serug, Nahor, Terah, and finally

28.verse: Our ancestor Abraham, who formed our people’s initial covenant with God, fathered two sons: Isaac and Ishmael.

29.verse: Ishmael fathered Nebaioth, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,

32.verse: Abraham also fathered sons by a concubine, Keturah: Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. Jokshan’s sons were Sheba and Dedan.

33.verse: Midian’s sons were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah.

34.verse: Abraham’s second son, Isaac, fathered two sons: Esau (the ancestor of Edom) and Israel (our ancestor).

35.verse: The sons of Esau were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.

36.verse: Eliphaz fathered Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, and by Timna, Amalek.

37.verse: Reuel fathered Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.

38.verse: Seir fathered Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.

39.verse: Lotan (whose sister was Timna) fathered Hori and Homam.

40.verse: Shobal fathered Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. Zibeon fathered Aiah and Anah.

41.verse: Anah’s son was Dishon, who fathered Hamran, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.

42.verse: Ezer fathered Bilhan, Zaavan, and Jaakan. Dishan (son of Seir) fathered Uz and Aran.

43.verse: These men were kings in Edom long before our ancestors reigned in Israel. Bela (the son of Beor) ruled the city of Dinhabah.

44.verse: When Bela died, Jobab (the son of Zerah of Bozrah) succeeded him.

45.verse: When Jobab died, Husham (a Temanite) became king.

46.verse: When Husham died, Hadad (the son of Bedad who crushed Midian in the field of Moab) succeeded Husham and renamed the city Avith.

47.verse: When Hadad died, Samlah of Masrekah succeeded him.

48.verse: When Samlah died, Shaul of Rehoboth by the Euphrates River succeeded him.

49.verse: When Shaul died, Baal-hanan (the son of Achbor) became king.

50.verse: When Baal-hanan died, Hadad ascended to the throne. Hadad named his city Pai. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Mezahab.

51.verse: When Hadad died, the monarchy crumbled and Edom was ruled by chiefs: Timna, Aliah, Jetheth,

1.verse: The sons of our ancestor Israel (the brother of Esau) were the forefathers of the twelve tribes: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,

2.verse: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.

3.verse: The sons of Judah (Er, Onan, and Shelah) were born to his wife Bath-shua of Canaan. Er (Judah’s firstborn) was wicked in the eyes of the Eternal One, so He put him to death. Er’s widow (and Judah’s own daughter-in-law),

4.verse: Tamar, gave birth to Judah’s youngest children, Perez and Zerah, giving Judah a total of five sons.

5.verse: Perez fathered Hezron and Hamul.

6.verse: Zerah fathered five sons: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara.

7.verse: The son of Carmi (the grandson of Zimri) was Achar, the troublemaker in Israel who violated the ban against taking the spoils of Jericho.

8.verse: The son of Ethan was Azariah.

9.verse: King David descended from Perez’s first son. Hezron fathered Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.

10.verse: Ram fathered Amminadab, and Amminadab fathered Nahshon, the leader of the tribe of Judah.

11.verse: Nahshon’s son was Salma, who fathered Boaz.

12.verse: Boaz fathered Obed, and Obed’s son was Jesse. Jesse had seven sons:

13.verse: Eliab (his firstborn), Abinadab (the second), Shimea (the third),

14.verse: Nethanel (the fourth), Raddai (the fifth),

15.verse: Ozem (the sixth), and David (the seventh).

16.verse: David had two sisters: Zeruiah and Abigail. The three sons of Zeruiah were Abshai, Joab, and Asahel.

17.verse: Abigail married Jether the Ishmaelite and gave birth to Amasa.

18.verse: Hezron’s son Caleb had sons by his wife, Azubah, and by Jerioth. Jerioth’s sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.

19.verse: When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who gave birth to Hur.

20.verse: Hur fathered Uri, and Uri’s son was Bezalel.

21.verse: After that Hezron married the daughter of Machir (the father of Gilead) when he was 60 years old. She gave birth to Segub.

22.verse: Segub fathered Jair, who had 23 cities in the land of Gilead.

23.verse: But Geshur and Aram conquered the 23 cities of Jair and the villages of Kenath—60 cities total. The conquerors were the sons of Machir (the father of Gilead).

24.verse: After Hezron died in Caleb-ephrathah, Abijah (Hezron’s wife) gave birth to Ashhur, the leader of Tekoa.

25.verse: Jerahmeel (the firstborn of Hezron) had five sons: Ram (the firstborn), Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.

26.verse: Jerahmeel had another wife, Atarah, who gave birth to Onam.

27.verse: Ram fathered Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.

28.verse: Onam fathered Shammai and Jada. Shammai’s sons were Nadab and Abishur.

29.verse: Abishur’s wife was Abihail, and she gave birth to Ahban and Molid.

30.verse: Nadab’s sons were Seled and Appaim. Seled died without sons,

31.verse: but Appaim fathered Ishi. The son of Ishi was Sheshan, who fathered Ahlai.

32.verse: Shammai’s brother, Jada, fathered Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without sons, but

33.verse: Jonathan fathered Peleth and Zaza. They were the generation of Jerahmeel.

34.verse: Sheshan had no sons, only daughters, and he had a servant named Jarha, who was Egyptian.

35.verse: Although many of the Jews’ female ancestors are influential in the development of the nation of Israel—women such as Rahab, Jael, and Deborah who perform feats even men are too faint of heart to accomplish—the men are the ones who build wealth and power over the generations. Because of the way inheritances work, only a son can continue his family’s lineage. When a father dies, his property is divided among his sons, with the first son inheriting a double portion of the assets. Daughters are typically married off and take on the identities of their husbands’ families; so when a man dies without any sons, his family line ends and his assets are disbursed to the nearest male relatives. Sheshan married one daughter to Jarha (his Egyptian servant), and she gave birth to Attai.

36.verse: Attai fathered Nathan, and here are the 11 generations that descended from Nathan: Zabad,

42.verse: Caleb, the brother of Jerahmeel and son of Hezron, fathered Mesha (his firstborn and the father of Ziph) and Mareshah (the father of Hebron).

43.verse: Hebron fathered Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.

44.verse: Shema’s son, Raham, fathered Jorkeam, and his brother Rekem fathered Shammai.

45.verse: The son of Shammai was Maon, and Maon fathered Bethzur.

46.verse: Ephah (Caleb’s concubine) gave birth to Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran fathered Gazez.

47.verse: The sons of Jahdai were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.

48.verse: Maacah (another of Caleb’s concubines) bore Sheber, Tirhanah,

49.verse: Shaaph (the father of Madmannah), Sheva (the father of Machbena and Gibea), and a daughter, Achsah.

50.verse: These were the generations of Caleb through Hur (the firstborn of Caleb’s second wife Ephrathah) were Shobal (the father of Kiriath-jearim),

51.verse: Salma (the father of Bethlehem), and Hareph (the father of Beth-gader).

52.verse: Shobal, the father of Kiriath-jearim governed Haroeh (half of the Manahathites)

53.verse: and the families of Kiriath-jearim (the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites). From these came the Zorathites and the Eshtaolites.

54.verse: Salma governed Bethlehem and the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-joab, and the Zorites (half of the Manahathites).

55.verse: Families of scribes lived at Jabez: the Tirathites, the Shimeathites, and the Sucathites. Those are the Kenites who came from Hammath (the father of Rechab).

1.verse: The tradition of firstborn rights in inheritance and genealogy is often the norm in the ancient world, but God sees fit to rearrange customs and alter expectations. In such an important listing of Israel like the book of Chronicles—which marks out in detail the Israelite people all the way to Adam—Jacob’s firstborn Reuben is not mentioned until the third spot! The genealogy starts in chapter 4 with Judah and then moves to Simeon, Reuben, Gad, Manasseh, and Levi. The prominence of David from Judah’s line goes back to the Genesis stories that told of how Reuben, Simeon, and Levi all committed horrible sins that removed them from royal contention and headship over their brothers, who would later become twelve tribal groups. In a way, everything in Chronicles (from ancestry lists to temple building) is set around King David from Judah and his lineage up to the Babylonian exile, which concludes the book of Chronicles. The great king David fathered 6 sons during his 7½ years reigning in Hebron. Ahinoam the Jezreelitess gave birth to his first son, Amnon. Abigail the Carmelitess birthed his second son, Daniel.

2.verse: Maacah, the daughter of Talmai (king of Geshur) bore his third son, Absalom. His fourth son, Adonijah, was born to Haggith.

3.verse: Abital bore his fifth son, Shephatiah. Ithream was his sixth son, and was born to his wife, Eglah.

4.verse: These were the 6 sons born to him in Hebron during his 7½-year reign there. David then ruled from Jerusalem for 33 years.

5.verse: There, Bath-shua (the daughter of Ammiel) gave him 4 sons: Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon;

6.verse: and 9 other sons also were born there: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

7.verse: and 9 other sons also were born there: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

8.verse: and 9 other sons also were born there: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

9.verse: These were David’s sons, in addition to their sister, Tamar, and his concubines’ children.

10.verse: David’s son and successor, Solomon, had 15 generations of descendants: Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat,

11.verse: Joram, Ahaziah, Joash,

12.verse: Amaziah, Azariah, Jotham,

13.verse: Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh,

14.verse: Amon, and Josiah.

15.verse: Josiah’s sons were, in order from the firstborn to the last: Johanan, Jehoiakim, Zedekiah, and Shallum.

16.verse: The sons of Jehoiakim were Jeconiah and Zedekiah.

17.verse: The sons of Jeconiah (who was taken prisoner by Nebuchadnezzar) were Shealtiel,

18.verse: Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.

19.verse: The sons of Pedaiah were Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel fathered Meshullam and Hananiah, and their sister, Shelomith.

20.verse: He had five other children, Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-hesed.

21.verse: Hananiah fathered Pelatiah and Jeshaiah, the sons of Rephaiah, the sons of Arnan, the sons of Obadiah, and the sons of Shecaniah.

22.verse: Shecaniah had six descendants: his son Shemaiah, and his grandsons Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat.

23.verse: Neariah fathered three sons: Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam.

24.verse: Elioenai fathered seven sons: Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani.

1.verse: Each tribe is influential in the nation of Israel and has the honor of being descended from the Jews’ ancestor Jacob, but the tribe of Judah has prominence and power. From this tribe comes Israel’s monarchy, even though their forefather Judah was not the oldest son and therefore not the one who would have been expected to father kings. The selection of Judah as the progenitor of kings demonstrates that God is in control of His people even when tradition and convention are contrary to His ways. Judah’s lineage descended as so: Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.

2.verse: Shobal fathered Reaiah (the father of Jahath and grandfather of Ahumai and Lahad). They were the families of the Zorathites.

3.verse: Etam fathered three sons, Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash, and their sister, Hazzelelponi.

4.verse: Penuel fathered Gedor, and Ezer fathered Hushah. These are the sons of Hur, who was the firstborn of Ephrathah, who fathered Bethlehem.

5.verse: Ashhur, the leader of Tekoa, had two wives: Helah and Naarah.

6.verse: Naarah gave birth to Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari.

7.verse: Helah gave birth to Zereth, Izhar, and Ethnan.

8.verse: Koz fathered Anub, Zobebah, and the families of Harum’s son, Aharhel.

9.verse: Jabez, whose name commemorates his mother’s labor pains, was more honorable than his brothers.

10.verse: He asked the God of Israel, “Please bless me and extend my territory. Let Your hand be with me and guard me from harm so I will not experience pain as my mother did.” And God did just that.

11.verse: Shuhah’s brother Chelub fathered Mehir, who fathered Eshton.

12.verse: Eshton fathered Beth-rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah who fathered Ir-nahash. These are the men of Recah.

13.verse: Kenaz fathered Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel’s sons were Hathath and Meonothai.

14.verse: Meonothai fathered Ophrah. Seraiah’s son was Joab, the father of Ge-harashim, the skilled workers.

15.verse: Caleb (the son of Jephunneh) fathered Iru, Elah, and Naam. Elah’s son was Kenaz.

16.verse: Jehallelel fathered Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.

17.verse: Ezrah fathered Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Jether’s wife bore Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah (the father of Eshtemoa). These are the sons of Bithia (Mered’s wife and Pharaoh’s daughter).

18.verse: His Judahite wife birthed Jered (the father of Gedor), Heber (the father of Soco), and Jekuthiel (the father of Zanoah).

19.verse: Hodiah’s wife (the sister of Naham) gave birth to the fathers of Keilah the Garmite and Eshtemoa the Maacathite.

20.verse: Shimon fathered Amnon, Rinnah, Benhanan, and Tilon. Ishi fathered Zoheth and Ben-zoheth.

21.verse: Judah’s son Shelah fathered Er (the father of Lecah), Laadah (the father of Mareshah), and the families of linen workers at Beth-ashbea,

22.verse: Jokim, the men of Cozeba, Joash, Saraph (who ruled in Moab), and Jashubi-lehem. This record is ancient.

23.verse: They were the potters who lived in Netaim and Gederah, working for the king.

24.verse: The sons of Simeon were Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, and Shaul.

25.verse: Shaul’s lineage descended Shallum, Mibsam, and Mishma,

26.verse: and the sons of Mishma were Hammuel, Zaccur, and Shimei.

27.verse: Shimei fathered 16 sons and 6 daughters, but his brothers did not have many sons and their tribes were not as large as the Judahites.

28.verse: Until David united the tribes into one nation, Shimei’s descendants lived at Beersheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,

31.verse: Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim. These were their cities until David became king.

32.verse: Their five city-states were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan,

33.verse: near the city of Baal. These were recorded in the genealogy of their villages:

35.verse: Joel, Jehu (son of Joshibiah, son of Seraiah, son of Asiel),

36.verse: Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,

37.verse: Ziza (son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah).

38.verse: These were chiefs, and their clans increased rapidly.

39.verse: They sought pastures for their flocks from the gate of Gedor to the east side of its surrounding valley.

40.verse: There they found a rich pasture and abundant, quiet, and peaceful land. The Hamites inhabited the land

41.verse: until the Simeonites attacked them during the reign of Judah’s king Hezekiah. They completely destroyed the tents and the Meunites who lived there. The Simeonites now live in their place, where there is pastureland for the flocks.

42.verse: Five hundred Simeonites went to Mount Seir, led by the sons of Ishi: Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel.

43.verse: There they killed the remaining Amalekites, and they live on that mountain until this day.

1.verse: Because Reuben slept with his father’s concubine, he forfeited his rights as the firstborn of Israel, his monetary inheritance and his political position as the leader of the nation of Israel. Although Reuben’s inheritance and birthright were given to Joseph, Judah’s descendants became the rulers of Israel.

2.verse: Because Reuben slept with his father’s concubine, he forfeited his rights as the firstborn of Israel, his monetary inheritance and his political position as the leader of the nation of Israel. Although Reuben’s inheritance and birthright were given to Joseph, Judah’s descendants became the rulers of Israel.

3.verse: Reuben’s sons (the firstborn of Israel) were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

4.verse: The descendants of Joel were Shemaiah, Gog, Shimei,

5.verse: Micah, Reaiah, Baal,

6.verse: and Beerah. Beerah (who led the Reubenites) was exiled by Tilgath-pilneser, the king of Assyria who destroyed Israel and exiled the inhabitants.

7.verse: His kinsmen led their families in the order of their generations: Jeiel was the first chief, then Zechariah,

8.verse: Bela of Aroer (son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel), Nebo, and finally Baal-meon.

9.verse: The Reubenite territory stretched to the Euphrates River Valley because their cattle had increased in the land of Gilead.

10.verse: During Saul’s reign they slaughtered the Hagrites and seized their territory east of Gilead.

11.verse: The Gadites lived across from the Reubenites between Bashan and Salecah.

12.verse: Joel was the chief, and Shapham was his second in command, then Janai and Shaphat in Bashan.

13.verse: There were seven clans in the tribe: Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.

14.verse: These were the sons of Abihail (son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz).

15.verse: Ahi (son of Abdiel and grandson of Guni) was chief of a clan.

16.verse: These leaders lived in Gilead, in Bashan, and in its towns. Their pastures filled the lands of Sharon.

17.verse: Their genealogies were recorded during the reigns of Jotham, king of Judah, and Jeroboam, king of Israel.

18.verse: The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh were skillful warriors who carried shields, wielded swords, and shot arrows. There were 44,760 who conquered the Hagrites, Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab.

19.verse: The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh were skillful warriors who carried shields, wielded swords, and shot arrows. There were 44,760 who conquered the Hagrites, Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab.

20.verse: They defeated the Hagrites and all who were with them because they asked for God’s help during the battle and trusted in Him, and their plea was granted.

21.verse: They seized 100,000 men and their herds: 50,000 camels, 250,000 sheep, and 2,000 donkeys.

22.verse: Many of the enemies died because the men were fighting God’s battle. The tribes then lived in these conquered lands until the exile.

23.verse: The numerous members of the half-tribe of Manasseh lived between Bashan and Baal-hermon, between Senir and Mount Hermon.

24.verse: The clan leaders were famous and glorious men: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel.

25.verse: But they disobeyed the God of their fathers, prostituting themselves to the pagan gods whom God had destroyed in front of them.

26.verse: So the God of Israel awakened the king of Assyria, Pul or Tilgath-pilneser, to exile the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. The people were taken from Israel to live in Halah, in Habor, in Hara, and by the river of Gozan, where they remain today.

1.verse: Levi fathered Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

2.verse: Kohath’s sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

3.verse: The children of Amram were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron fathered Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

4.verse: Eleazar’s lineage descended 21 generations until the exile: Phinehas, Abishua,

5.verse: Bukki, Uzzi,

6.verse: Zerahiah, Meraioth,

7.verse: Amariah, Ahitub,

8.verse: Zadok, Ahimaaz,

9.verse: Azariah, Johanan,

10.verse: Azariah (he was priest in Solomon’s temple which was constructed in Jerusalem),

11.verse: Amariah, Ahitub,

12.verse: Zadok, Shallum,

13.verse: Hilkiah, Azariah,

14.verse: Seraiah, and Jehozadak

15.verse: (one of those from Jerusalem and Judah whom the Eternal One exiled by Nebuchadnezzar).

16.verse: While the tribe of Judah boasts the kingly lineage, specifically Israel’s beloved kings David and Solomon, the tribe of Levi is the priestly tribe. These men are at the center of the worship of the Lord, performing the daily rituals and sacrifices required in the law. These are the Levite clans according to their patronage: Levi fathered Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.

17.verse: Gershom’s sons were Libni and Shimei.

18.verse: Kohath’s sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

19.verse: Merari’s sons were Mahli and Mushi. These are the Levitical clans.

20.verse: Gershom’s lineage descended seven generations: Libni, Jahath, Zimmah,

21.verse: Joah, Iddo, Zerah, and Jeatherai.

22.verse: Kohath’s lineage descended ten generations: Amminadab, Korah, Assir,

23.verse: Elkanah, Ebiasaph, Assir,

24.verse: Tahath, Uriel, Uzziah, and Shaul.

25.verse: The sons of Elkanah were Amasai and Ahimoth.

26.verse: Elkanah’s lineage descended six generations: Zophai, Nahath,

28.verse: Samuel’s sons were Joel (the firstborn) and Abijah (the second).

29.verse: Merari’s lineage descended seven generations: Mahli, Libni, Shimei, Uzzah,

31.verse: After the chest of the covenant came to rest in the tent of the congregation, King David appointed the following Levites to be the musicians in the temple.

32.verse: They ministered with songs with respect to their responsibilities outlined for them at the congregation tent until our king Solomon built the temple in Jerusalem.

33.verse: These served with their sons: From the Kohathites was Heman the singer (son of Joel, son of Samuel,

34.verse: son of Elkanah, son of Jeroham, son of Eliel, son of Toah,

35.verse: son of Zuph, son of Elkanah, son of Mahath, son of Amasai,

36.verse: son of Elkanah, son of Joel, son of Azariah, son of Zephaniah,

37.verse: son of Tahath, son of Assir, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah,

38.verse: son of Izhar, son of Kohath, son of Levi, son of Israel).

39.verse: On Heman’s right stood his cousin Asaph (son of Berechiah, son of Shimea,

40.verse: son of Michael, son of Baaseiah, son of Malchijah,

41.verse: son of Ethni, son of Zerah, son of Adaiah,

42.verse: son of Ethan, son of Zimmah, son of Shimei,

43.verse: son of Jahath, son of Gershom, son of Levi).

44.verse: On Heman’s left stood their cousin from the Merarites, Ethan (son of Kishi, son of Abdi, son of Malluch,

45.verse: son of Hashabiah, son of Amaziah, son of Hilkiah,

46.verse: son of Amzi, son of Bani, son of Shemer,

47.verse: son of Mahli, son of Mushi, son of Merari, son of Levi).

48.verse: Their cousins from other Levitical clans served the congregation tent of the house of God.

49.verse: Aaron and his sons performed the holiest work: they gave burnt offerings and incense offerings. These offerings atoned for Israel, according to all God’s servant Moses had commanded.

50.verse: The lineage of Aaron descended 11 generations: Eleazar, Phinehas, Abishua,

1.verse: If the Levites are servants of the temple, then why can they live anywhere besides Jerusalem? The temple calendar is set up so that each Levite only serves for two weeks each year at the temple. For the remainder of the year, the Levites are spread throughout the nation and live in pastoral settings, planting grains and tending flocks just as most of the Israelites do. But they have one more function. Within the various cities, they collect the temple taxes that each Israelite owes based on the tribal area where he lives. This way the Levites keep all of the Israelites accountable to God year round. Issachar fathered four sons: Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.

2.verse: Tola’s sons were Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, and Samuel. These were heroic warriors, and their clans numbered 22,600 during King David’s reign.

3.verse: Uzzi’s son Izrahiah fathered Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah, and all were the chiefs of their own generations.

4.verse: The clans these men led numbered 36,000 troops because the men had many wives and sons.

5.verse: These clans, in addition to the other clans of Issachar, totaled 87,000 heroic warriors.

6.verse: Benjamin fathered three sons: Bela, Becher, and Jediael.

7.verse: Bela’s five sons were Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri. They were chiefs of their clans, heroic warriors numbering 22,034.

8.verse: Becher’s sons were Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, and Alemeth.

9.verse: They were chiefs in their clans, heroic warriors numbering 20,200.

10.verse: Jediael’s son was Bilhan. Bilhan’s sons were Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, and Ahishahar.

11.verse: They were chiefs in their clans, heroic warriors numbering 17,200.

12.verse: And Ir fathered Shuppim and Huppim. Aher fathered Hushim.

13.verse: Israel’s concubine Bilhah gave birth to Naphtali, who fathered Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum.

14.verse: The sons of Manasseh and his Aramean concubine were Asriel and Machir (father of Gilead).

15.verse: Machir found a wife for Huppim and Shuppim, whose sister was Maacah. The second sister was Zelophehad, who had only daughters.

16.verse: Machir’s wife, Maacah, bore Peresh. His brother was Sheresh, who fathered Ulam and Rakem.

17.verse: Ulam’s son was Bedan. These were the sons of Gilead (son of Machir, son of Manasseh).

18.verse: His sister, Hammolecheth, gave birth to Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.

19.verse: Shemida fathered Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.

20.verse: Ephraim’s lineage descended seven generations: Shuthelah, Bered, Tahath, Eleadah, Tahath,

21.verse: Zabad, and Shuthelah. Ezer and Elead (Shuthelah’s sons) were killed by men of the Philistine city Gath because the brothers stole livestock.

22.verse: Their father Ephraim mourned many days, and his relatives comforted him.

23.verse: His wife became pregnant and birthed Beriah (whose name means “misfortune” and commemorates the tragedy in Ephraim’s family).

24.verse: His daughter, Sheerah, built lower and upper Beth-horon and Uzzen-sheerah.

25.verse: His sons were Rephah and Resheph. Resheph’s lineage descended seven generations: Telah, Tahan,

26.verse: Ladan, Ammihud, Elishama,

Their borders lined Manasseh’s territories: the cities and towns of Beth-shean, Taanach, Megiddo, and Dor.

29.verse: Although these ancestral and tribal lists seem tedious and monotonous, they are absolutely essential for marking identity and place in the postexilic community. For example, a person from Saul’s line among Benjamin may have positioned himself for the Judean throne during a time of political and economic weakness. If such a person has arisen from Benjamin or any other tribe such as Ephraim, which is the dominant tribe of the Northern Kingdom, then the scribes in Jerusalem can simply consult the tribal lists in the book of Chronicles. These lists are not just for noting the “insiders” and “outsiders,” but they also serve the purpose of setting forth a long and special covenant identity before the Eternal One and the specific roles within His nation and people called “Israel.” The ancestry lists of Chronicles support the one who says, “I am a singer before the Eternal One,” and those who say, “We are guards at the house of our God.” In Gibeon, Jeiel (the father of Gibeon) lived with his wife Maacah.

1.verse: All the tribes of Israel were recorded in the book of the kings of Israel; then Judah was exiled to Babylon for their unfaithfulness to God.

2.verse: It might seem strange that the Jews’ genealogy continues seamlessly from pre-exilic Judah and Israel to their return home, especially since the generations of people who live in exile are lost from the list. But it is important that those who return, who become known as “Jews” while they are exiled in Babylon, are connected to the Israelites. The Jews are the continuation of God’s covenant, so they should remember the long history of faithful ancestors and use them as examples in building the new Israel. At the end of our exile, the first people who returned to their cities were Israelites, Levites, the priests and the temple servants.

3.verse: Some people from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh lived in Jerusalem:

4.verse: Uthai the son of Ammihud, son of Omri, son of Imri, son of Bani, son of Perez, son of Judah.

5.verse: From the Shilonites were Asaiah (the firstborn) and his sons.

6.verse: From the Zerahites were Jeuel and 690 relatives.

7.verse: From the Benjaminites were Sallu (son of Meshullam, son of Hodaviah, son of Hassenuah),

8.verse: Ibneiah (son of Jeroham), Elah (son of Uzzi, son of Michri), Meshullam (son of Shephatiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah),

9.verse: and 956 relatives. All these were leaders of their clans.

10.verse: From the priests were Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jachin,

11.verse: Azariah (son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub—the chief officer of the temple),

12.verse: Adaiah (son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah), Maasai (son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer),

13.verse: and their chiefs. These men totaled 1,760 workers in the temple. These were all talented men fit for service in the temple.

14.verse: The Levites who returned included Shemaiah (son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, son of Merari),

15.verse: Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, Mattaniah (son of Mica, son of Zichri, son of Asaph),

16.verse: Obadiah (son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun), and Berechiah (son of Asa, son of Elkanah). They lived among the Netophathites.

17.verse: The gatekeepers, who guarded the entrances and performed other daily chores, were Shallum (stationed at the king’s gate in the east), Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives.

18.verse: The gatekeepers, who guarded the entrances and performed other daily chores, were Shallum (stationed at the king’s gate in the east), Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives.

19.verse: These were the gatekeepers for the congregation tent and monitored activities there (as their fathers had ruled the camp of the Eternal One as keepers of the entrance): Shallum (son of Kore, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah) and his fellow Korahites.

20.verse: Phinehas (son of Eleazar) ruled them previously, and the Eternal was with him.

21.verse: Zechariah (son of Meshelemiah) was gatekeeper at the entrance of the congregation tent.

22.verse: All the men who were gatekeepers numbered 212. They were recorded in the local genealogies and were chosen by King David and the seer Samuel.

23.verse: They and their sons guarded the gates of the temple and the congregation tent.

24.verse: The gatekeepers were stationed on all sides: to the north, south, east, and west.

25.verse: Their relatives joined the gatekeepers once per week to keep them company.

26.verse: The four chief gatekeepers (who were Levites) had the important task of controlling the chambers and treasuries in the temple.

27.verse: Because guarding was their primary task, they spent their nights watching the temple and opened it each morning.

28.verse: Others were in charge of the vessels of service; the vessels were counted as they were brought into and taken out of the temple.

29.verse: Still others were in charge of the sanctuary’s furniture and utensils, and of the flour, wine, oil, frankincense, and spices.

30.verse: Some of the sons of the priests mixed these spices.

31.verse: Mattithiah (a Levite and the firstborn of Shallum the Korahite) was responsible for things baked in pans for offerings.

32.verse: Some of their Kohathite relatives baked the unleavened bread used as showbread every sabbath.

33.verse: These are the singers, the chiefs of the Levites during their own generations, who lived in the chambers of the temple in Jerusalem free from other service because they worked day and night.

34.verse: All these men were the chiefs of the Levites during their own generations, and they all lived in Jerusalem.

35.verse: All priests may be Levites, but not all Levites are priests. Priests are descendants of Aaron, Israel’s first high priest, and perform sacrifices in the temple. Levites who are descendants of the other Levite patriarchs perform all the other duties necessary in the temple; they are elders, custodians, musicians, assistants, handymen, gatekeepers, treasurers, etc. All jobs are equally necessary to the functioning of the temple, so no one of them should be more highly regarded than another. Even the high priest is no more important than the young Levite who sweeps the floor every day. Jeiel (the leader of Gibeon) lived in Gibeon with his wife Maacah.

36.verse: Their firstborn son was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,

38.verse: Mikloth fathered Shimeam. These lived with their relatives in Jerusalem, across from their other relatives.

39.verse: Ner fathered Kish, whose son was Saul (father of Jonathan, Malchi-shua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal).

40.verse: Jonathan’s son was Merib-baal, and Merib-baal’s son was Micah.

41.verse: Micah fathered Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
